transcript:
Therapist: Emilio, you mentioned that your depressive symptoms first emerged during adolescence. Can you tell me more about what was happening in your life during that time?

Patient: Well, I was struggling a lot with my gender identity and trying to figure out who I was. I knew I was different from a young age, but it wasn't until my teenage years that I really started to understand what it meant to be transgender. It was a confusing and isolating time for me.

Therapist: It sounds like you were going through a lot of emotional turmoil during that period. How did your family and peers react to your gender identity?

Patient: My adoptive family was actually really supportive. They loved me unconditionally and just wanted me to be happy. But at school, it was a different story. I faced a lot of bullying and harassment from other kids who didn't understand or accept me. It made me feel like an outsider and really took a toll on my self-esteem.

Therapist: That must have been incredibly difficult, to feel rejected by your peers at such a vulnerable time. How do you think those experiences have impacted you in the long term?

Patient: I think it's made it hard for me to trust people and open up. I always feel like I have to be on guard, like I'm waiting for someone to judge me or reject me. It's also made me really hard on myself. I feel like I have to be perfect all the time to make up for being different.

Therapist: It's understandable that those experiences would leave you feeling guarded and self-critical. It's a common response to trauma and rejection. I wonder if we could explore how those patterns of thinking and behaving might be contributing to your depression now.

Patient: Yeah, I think they definitely play a role. I put a lot of pressure on myself to be successful and to make my family proud. But at the same time, I don't really believe that I'm good enough. It's like I'm constantly trying to prove myself, but I never feel like I measure up.

Therapist: That's a really insightful observation, Emilio. It sounds like you have a lot of inner turmoil between striving for perfection and feeling inadequate. How does that conflict show up in your daily life?

Patient: I think it shows up in my work a lot. I'm always pushing myself to do more and be better, but I never really feel satisfied with what I accomplish. And when I do make mistakes or fall short, I beat myself up about it for days. It's exhausting.

Therapist: It sounds like that cycle of self-criticism and perfectionism is really taking a toll on you emotionally and physically. I'm wondering if we could start to look at some of those thought patterns more closely and see if there might be alternative ways of thinking that could be more helpful for you.
